title: Fourth Council Directive 88/14/EEC of 22 December 1987 on summertime arrangements
header:
FOURTH  COUNCIL DIRECTIVE
of 22 December 1987
on summertime arrangements
(88/14/EEC)
THE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES
main_body: For the purposes of this Directive the expression 'summertime period' means the period of the year during which the time is advanced by 60 minutes in relation to the time for the rest of the year.
Member States shall take the measures necessary to ensure that in each Member State the summertime period for 1989 begins at 1 a.m. Greenwich Mean Time on Sunday 26 March 1989.

The Member States, apart from Ireland and the United Kingdom, shall take the measures necessary to ensure that the summertime period for 1989 ends at 1 a.m. Greenwich Mean Time, on Sunday 24 September 1989.
Ireland and the United Kingdom shall take the measures necessary to ensure that the summertime period for 1989 ends at 1 a.m. Greenwich Mean Time, on Sunday 29 October 1989.
The Council, acting on a proposal from the Commission, shall adopt by 1 January 1989 the arrangements to apply from 1990 onwards.
This Directive shall not apply to the overseas territories of the Member States.
This Directive is addressed to the Member States.
attachments:
Done at Brussels, 22 December 1987.
For the Council
The President
N. WILHJELM
